texts.definition: The goal or phase of learning the layout of a game world, or locating specific parts or objects within it.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal or phase of learning the layout of a game world, or locating specific parts or objects within it.</style>

Players may not have complete knowledge of game worlds as they begin playing games. This may be due to the worlds being larger than can be viewed at once or that some areas of them are kept secret until players have moved their game elements into the proximity of these areas. Games created in this fashion give players the goal of uncovering unknown areas through <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style>.
Note: This pattern is rather wide in scope, ranging both from specific goals in games to a substantial phase of gameplay during game instances.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Games with large game worlds, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%20series">Just Cause series</link></style>, require players to explore them in order to finish them. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> have exploration as a major gameplay element as players start game instances knowing very little about the game worlds. To ensure that exploration is needed in new game instances, the games can generate new game worlds for each instance.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

A prerequisite for needing to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> is that something needs to be found (or surveyed) in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. Examples of things that need to be found include <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-resources">Secret Resources</link></style>, and any type of <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style> not already located. Giving players reasons to do <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> can indirectly cause <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> since players may discover unexpected things while doing the navigation. Two basic requirements for making exploration non-trivial is that players cannot have complete overviews of the entire <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> - often done through using <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> as players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> - and that <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> is non-deterministic, i.e. players have to make decisions where to explore. <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> can be used to support <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> in regards to the explorations (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Drakborgen">Drakborgen</link></style> is an example of this) while <style="Link"><link="procedurally-generated-game-worlds">Procedurally Generated Game Worlds</link></style> can be used to create large <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> to explore (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elite%20series">Elite series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%20series">Just Cause series</link></style>). For <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Expansions">Expansions</link></style> may instead be necessary to maintain a possibility or need of exploration over time. The use of <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> in games can guarantee a form of <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> in that unvisited <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> by definition are unexplored areas.

Besides these two requirements of <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style>, the pattern can be modulated in many ways. <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> can make it more difficult while <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> can make it easier; <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> can do both and also be points of references helping with <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> (as can <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>). It may only be possible for those that have the appropriate <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technologies">Technologies</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> and access to this can be controlled through when <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> are provided.

In many cases exploration consist of intended or emergent <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style>, e.g. finding a series of <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>, locating <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> that one as a player have been told about, or defeating <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> met. Games using <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> often use <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> as <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> to drive the gameplay progression forward.  Besides being a cause for <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> to begin with, <style="Link"><link="fog-war">Fog of War</link></style> that reappears in unsupervised areas can make it necessary to engage in exploration of areas already visited. <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> can help <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> by creating representations of areas as they are visited (but this may also sabotage the activity if they reveal features before players themselves notice them); <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style> can do the same but typically have diegetic information about placed not yet visited. <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style> can make exploration into more tangible experiences as players can create the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> as they explore them. <style="Link"><link="grind-achievements">Grind Achievements</link></style> can be used to encourage players to engage in already possible exploration.

The pattern can be seen as a special case of combining the goals of <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style>, and - like the latter of these - requires either <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> differs from <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> in that the places, areas, and area boundaries are not known and the player has to get more information about them when there is <style="Link"><link="fog-war">Fog of War</link></style>. Requiring <style="Link"><link="physical-navigation">Physical Navigation</link></style> is a way to modify <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> by making players move around in a physical environment rather than in a virtual or abstract one.

<style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> is often an initial phase in many games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>, which then gradually moves over to other phases. In X4 games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style> this is the first in the series of <style="CurrentLink">(Game World) Exploration</style>, <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="extermination">Extermination</link></style>. As such, it is often incompatible with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style>. As a contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> can also take place between game instances in <style="Link"><link="legacy-games">Legacy Games</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

Dealing with the exploration of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, the pattern <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Diegetic%20Patterns">Diegetic Pattern</link></style> even if it focuses more on how players perceive the diegesis than how it is constructed.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> is in essence the aim of finding game elements or charting <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. While this is typically done through <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, the actual traversal done while doing this is not so important as the exploratory action this provides (see Linderoth 2010 for a discussion on performatory and exploratory actions in games). The activity requires <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> of the layout unless some <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style>, shows the already-explored areas. The use of <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> can through this modulate <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> but when they show the layout of parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that have not yet been visited it instead works against the purpose of having exploration goals.

As <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> relies upon the environment being unknown to players, the presence of goals related to this ensure that players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Foresight">Limited Foresight</link></style> and may experience <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> and the feeling of discovering new places - including the <style="Link"><link="illusionary-rewards">Illusionary Rewards</link></style> of finding aesthetically pleasing <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> - can give players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spatial%20Engrossment">Spatial Engrossment</link></style> while undertaking <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style>. One special case relate to this is <style="Link"><link="easter-eggs">Easter Eggs</link></style> - although these need to exist independently of goals of exploring <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, providing goals of <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> can be said to instantiate them since players would otherwise be very unlikely to ever encounter them.

The <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Foresight">Limited Foresight</link></style> required of <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> can be linked to the development of players' skills at playing a game. By coupling the search for <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style> with their introduction into gameplay, a game can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> to novice players.

<style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> has a dual relation to <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. While some <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> can require players to engage in exploration, others that have known locations that should be visited can instead discourage players from engaging in exploration since this is unnecessary from an local efficiency perspective.

As <style="CurrentLink">Game World Exploration</style> is often in focus during the first phases of games, it in many cases qualifies to define the <style="Link"><link="startgame">Startgame</link></style> of these games.
